body.p: We appreciate the comments by Dr. Ren and others: The discussion is warmly welcomed. Our study was designed to investigate the biochemical responses of dental structures after being bleached with a commercial product. We selected 35% H2O2 with neutral to slightly acidic pH (6-7) because its composition is similar to that of several products routinely used for in-office tooth whitening. Our study did not intend to test different products; hence it does not lack controls.

We agree that the enamel of young adults is generally more permeable, making this population more prone to immediate harmful effects. Conversely, repeatedly subjecting the teeth to bleaching agents may compensate for the protection offered by reduced permeability with age (Goldberg et al., 2010). We bring up this point at the end of our article, where the sentence “…provokes biological responses of dental tissues that can be clinically adverse in the long term” continues with “and/or after recurring bleaching treatments. Individuals intending to undergo dental bleaching should be warned about the biological hazards potentially caused by the use of extensive and unbridled H2O2.” Our study showed that in-office bleaching is far from being just a harmless cosmetic procedure.

We share with Dr. Ren the concern for the potentially harmful effects of repeated whitening treatments – the effects that may be seen only after several years (SCCP, 2007) and are therefore practically impossible to study in clinical surroundings.
